captions.text:
• From books marked up to well over their
physical value to expensive food you buy simply

because you're too lazy to walk down the street,
we count 15 money sinks found everyday consuming

pieces of your wallet for no reason
15 - All You Can Eat Buffets,

• A lot of people will contest this isn't
a rip-off, that they do very much enjoy the

luxury of being able to eat as much as they
want

• But here's a reality check - you're paying
for that peace of mind, not the actual food

which, unless you've been starving yourself
out on the open sea for over a month, you'll

generally consume about a standard restaurant
dish - but you're now paying twice or three

times as much
• Bear in mind this is just an average statistic,

and of course there'll be exceptions from
time to time, but most people waste their

money on this instead of just buying a standard
meal

14 - School Textbooks,
• This mostly applies to high school and

above, an issue becoming less dire with each
passing year - textbooks required for class

with more than a 500% markup of price
• If you don't buy the book, you'll fail

the class, and you can't use the previous
years edition because it's now out-of-date

- even used books have one-time use access
codes that render them crippled at the end

of the semester
• This daylight robbery hasn't gone unnoticed

by governments, a lot of them making the transition
to ebooks and internet-based information to

save families on unnecessary costs
13 - Funeral,

• This is one nobody likes to talk about,
but it's very important that you do since

funeral bills cause heart attacks all on their
own

• The average funeral cost can range from
anywhere between $5000 to $15,000 simply for

a hole to put them in, a granite plaque and
a quick limousine ride for your family

• A lot of the things you pay for you can
actually do yourself, like have a charity

collection for flowers, organise a carpool,
have the memorial at home instead - you'll

save thousands
12 - Budget Flights,

• You might look at something like EasyJet
or Jetstar if you need to get overseas but

can't afford the hefty costs involved, but
it's not as cheap as you think

• When you factor in the extra costs involved,
luggage processing fees, pre-paid food, credit

card percentage fees, it slowly climbs back
up to a proper airline price

• Of course, most budget airlines aren't
so bad in terms of service, but you WILL get

what you paid for
11 - Premium Petrol,

• A common misconception that putting this
"higher quality" fuel in your car will clean

out the engine and make it run better
• In reality, certain parts in your car

may or may not need them for mechanical reasons,
and if so then it'll have it clearly labeled

next to your fuel cap as well as inside your
owner's manual

• If you don't have these parts, then there
is absolutely no point putting premium fuel

in your car, you're just pouring money down
the drain for no reason whatsoever

10 - Printer Ink,
• One of the biggest scams out there, to

present a dirt-cheap printer and then markup
all the additional parts to crazy high prices

• The amount of ink you buy from one cartridge
is over 2,000 times cheaper than the same

quantity of petrol for your car - the only
way printer manufacturers can recoup their

losses
• Same with video game consoles, cheap until

you factor in all the game and DLC costs - but
even worse is that the amount of ink you get

in a cartridge has been slowly decreasing,
giving you LESS value for more dollar

9 - Branded Medicine,
• If you've been to a pharmacy for some

prescription pills, you'll likely have been
given the offer between the known popular

brand and generic chemist one
• A lot of people will get the known brand

simply to be safe, but like with premium petrol
it's all baloney - pharmacies are legally

obliged to use exactly the same chemical composition
in both bottles

• Think about it - can you imagine if your
local chemist offered you a dodgy, barely

working piece of medication at dirt cheap
price and then get away with it? The backlash

would be unbelievable
• Always go with the cheaper choice - you're

getting the same thing anyway
8 - Supermarket deals,

• You'll find these promotions all the time
- buy two of the thing you want for a slightly

discounted price, but the reality is, you're
paying extra for barely any reason

• It's a psychological ploy to squeeze a
bit of extra cash from your wallet, but even

worse is when supermarkets bump up the price
just before the promotion, meaning you almost

pay full price for two regardless
• If you see one of these deals, think long

and hard about whether you REALLY need, and
could use two of the thing you're buying - or

if you're throwing money out the window simply
for the illusion of a bargain

7 - Gym Membership,
• A lot of people waste their money on these

thinking they'll be economically motivated
to work out because they blew hundreds of

dollars on a year-long membership
• Sadly, most don't use their membership

anywhere near frequently enough to justify
the cost, and others don't go at all

• In some contracts, the gym will actually
prevent you from cancelling your membership

even if you lose your job or given military
orders to leave town

• Consider working out in your own home
using basic equipment everyday for an entire

year before joining one of these money sinks
6 - Bottled Water,

• The big marketing campaign was always
to present you with the image of a cool, clear

mountain stream - small villagers collecting
and bottling it for your consumption on store

shelves
• In reality, you're paying over $3 for

expensive tap water from a source you'll never
know about, possibly a big tap in some factory

three streets over, maybe run through filters
if you're lucky

• The difference is, tap water is damn near
free, you can easily check information on

your local water supply online, how it's treated,
violations that might've occurred and so forth

• Bottled water might've been urine recycled
several times and if so, you'll never find

out
5 - Extended Warranties,

• So you've bought a piece of furniture
or big, hefty appliance and you want to make

damn sure your investment hasn't gone to waste,
so you take on the extended warranty, usually

5 years
• Of course, more often than not you'll

be paying a premium for this service guarantee,
perhaps as much as a typical repair would

cost
• To sum up: you're insuring your purchase

for a repair over a period where you almost
certainly won't have any operating issues,

when you could, y'know, wait till it breaks
and call a repairman for the same price

4 - Hotel Mini-Bar,
• They already know, man, the hotel owners

know you're gonna rock up to your room, exhausted
from a hard day's work or travel, so they

stock the fridge or bar with all kinds of
nonsense

• The markup is one of the biggest rip-offs
on Earth - over a thousand percent just so

you can have your mars bar at 1am, and people
fall into that trap all the time

• It's really easy to bypass though - just
anticipate your midnight cravings and visit

a convenience store or supermarket ahead of
time, stock up on inexpensive calorie-ridden

sweets for an all-night buffet
3 - Movie Popcorn,

• These two words go hand-in-hand since
the dawn of cinema, so tightly fused that

nobody would dare speak up against it, like
bacon and eggs for breakfast it's just a part

of culture now
• Of course you don't want to be that one

idiot who refuses to shell out $15 for a tub
of popcorn for your family, and even though

it costs pennies to produce, you're still
buying a product marked up by a thousand percent

• The reason? According to industry analysts,
theatres barely make anything from ticket

sales alone, so they need to rely on popcorn
and candy sales

2 - Razor Blades,
• And here we have the most often stolen

item in any supermarket, the hilariously overpriced
razor blade

• You know something is wrong when, like
printers, the main unit is sold dirt cheap

and you look over to the accessory section
only to get a nosebleed and burst eye vessels

• Popcorn and hotel snacks might be marked
up by a thousand percent, but razor blades

approach 5 times that, for a blade on a strip
used to cut facial hair, an essential tool

if you plan to work at any job, ever
• Rumours suggest all razor companies conspire

to keep the prices high, and they've always
been that way

1 - Lottery Ticket
• Generally referred to as the "idiot tax",

an alternative to cutting your dollar notes
into little pieces by instead handing it over

a desk for a slip of paper worth nothing
• The chances of you actually winning the

lottery are so low, so minute that you literally
have a better chance of getting killed on

your way to buy the ticket than you do to
actually win the jackpot

• Of course, for some people it's all about
the possibility of winning, gives them hope

every week - and even though you and I know
it's a waste of time, for a lot of others

it means everything, and I'm alright with
that

title: 15 Biggest Ripoffs You're Still Paying For

comments.text:
A couple of things wrong. The water one especially. Go to London, mate. 
Taste the tap water after it has gone through your own filter then have a 
bottle of Buxton water. And Buxton water comes from a source that is 
NATURALLY filtered in the High Peak in the UK. You can find out all info 
about it and their bottling plant in the town of the same name. :)

Razor blades as well... Actually if you use a blade correctly it should 
last a lot longer than the cheaper options. You should have said certain 
companies. Check out articles by barbers that offers shaves. King of Shaves 
razor is expensive but you get what you pay for. The blades last a long 
time staying sharp meaning you don't have burn or need to use balm or 
moisturiser. You should have said about aftershave and shaving lotion being 
a rip off as a good razor and using a hot face towel is all you need. 
Alcohol and lotions actually clog up the skin.

Normally I agree with what you say but this video had some very silly and 
ignorant opinions. Along with rumours sold as facts. I would like to know 
how you think a stainless steel piercing is worth more than a pack of 
blades that are designed and take time to conceive and develop through R 
and D.

Sorry for the essay... I can never seem to keep my points concise.﻿

comments.text:
I believe that buffet not ripping off because if you say that ripping off 
is paying twice or 3 times more for the things you buy, there are much more 
things people pay more than that. And besides, I do not think that a 
customer expects to buy food/things for the same or almost the same price 
they would pay themselves if they decided to make /cook the product. Also, 
people pay money for time ( think , how much time you would spend buying 
products and cooking) and if it would be as delicious as it is when you go 
to a buffet in a  good restaurant, especially exotic one. Also , buy one 
get one free often works ( not always, but often).  As for water - it 
tastes different , depending on a company, and maybe you do not feel it, 
other people do. And the last , but not least, people , buying a lottery 
pay money not just for a piece of a paper but for a thrill, connected with 
a tiny but still a possible chance to win. It is strange  that you did not 
say about buying a cup of coffee in a fast food restaurants. That is where 
people ( devoted customers) pay so much more than if they just bought the 
best sorts of coffee and made their coffee at home. But then again, maybe 
they just trade money for time or a possibility to sit at their favourite 
restaurant and talk to their friends?﻿

comments.text:
Movie theatre concessions has to be marked up over 1000%. Like you said on 
opening night the theatres make less than 1% off box office sales. The 
longer the movie is out the higher the profit percentage. However, I've 
never saw the profit percentage go higher than 8%. So how does the movie 
theatre pay for operations. 1000% mark up an concessions product.

Operations consist of: power bill, water bill, gas bill, phone and internet 
bill, rent, property lease, labor costs, food and paper costs. 

Power bill on an average 12 screen cinema pushing at least 60,000 watts per 
auditorium. 14 hours a day, 365 days a year. Your talking about $40,000 
power bill a month.﻿

comments.text:
another supermarket ploy to be aware of for health reasons: whenever the 
meat or dairy in a supermarket is on sale, that shit's about to spoil by 
within the next 1-3 days.
I've worked in supermarkets that would even put AMMONIA  contaminated food 
products on the shelf if they thought they could hide the smell and they 
fired me for complaining about how INSANELY ILLEGAL this safety violation 
is!

If you live in a state where the main grocery store is meijer don't shop 
there.
they fired me for complaining about this shit and tried to say I violated a 
"non-disclosure agreement".
non-disclosure agreement is a red flag for a shady business every time.
ammonia spills MUST legally be disposed of by hazmat.
not only did meijer NOT call hazmat, they actually made the receiving 
employees get on the truck TOTALLY COVERED IN AMMONIA, BREATHE IN THE FUMES 
AND LOAD THE CONVEYER BELT BEFORE DUSTING OFF THE BOXES THAT HAD NO VISIBLE 
STAINS, SPRAYED THEM WITH FEBREZE AND THEN PUT THEM ON THE SHELVES!

The guy who they made get in that truck is now mentally retarded because of 
the brain damage he withstood during this criminal act and they still work 
him like a slave!
He almost never leaves the building and you can literally smell that he 
does not bathe properly!﻿

comments.text:
With medications, only the active ingredients have to be the same (name 
brand vs generic), the filler which makes up 75% of the tablet can be 
different; and in some cases (immuno-suppressants especially seem to have 
this problem) the type of filler used can inhibit absorption of the 
medication. ﻿

comments.text:
I only buy lottery tickets when i know i'm gonna win, and i do always win, 
how? I really don't know, it's about 2 tickets a year on average though, 
but i've got excellent timing so it seems.
And we once had a tv break down exactly one day after the warranty expired, 
extended warranty would give us a new tv would it break beyond repairing, 
and so it did 2 hours after the warrenty expired it broke down beyond 
repairing, probably installed to break down after said period of time, i 
still can't believe it.
And unlead oil is very good for certain engines, it's not really pooring 
money down the drain, especially good for smaller engines such as the ones 
from scooters.
And the all you can eat buffet, hmm i never saw an all you can eat buffet 
that costed more than a visit to a regular restuarant.
On average a regular resto visit would cost me 15€, same would go for an 
all you can eat buffet, plus having so much variaty is very nice. i'd pay 
an extra 5€ for that anytime, knowing that i won't be left craving for more 
with a 90/95% filled belly, no instead i'd be left craving for more but 
with my belly one hundred percent filled.
Can't express my feelings when i go to a restuarant only to sit there for 
45 mins untill my food is ready and i'm not hungry anymore and when i 
finished  (if i finish my plate, since i'm not hungry anymore but my 
stomach is still empty) my plate i'm not even entirely filled, sure i could 
order a dessert, but desserts i can buy at the bakery for even less money, 
you had better put that in your movie, buying desserts in a restuarant is a 
rip off, you get a desert you can eat in one bite for 4€ when you can buy a 
desert for 3€ at the bakery twice the size.
Like buying an ice cream in a restuarant is an even bigger rip off, 6€ for 
3 scoops of ice with half a strawberry and a piece of chocolate, holy shit 
and it's the same price for a milkshake, ice and milk and probably a banana 
or two costs a whopping 6€ but that's alright, just don't buy premium gas 
and you'll be alright, if you're driving a new modern vehicle that is, 
otherwise the feul will (might) damage your engine and the repairs, well 
those cost more money than you would have "lost" should you have bought 
premium gas.
But when i walk into a restaurant and all i have to do is take a plate and 
take whatever the fuck i want, well i'd take that over a regular resto 
visit any day, if i could afford it :)﻿

know to get one for you from some place like Sri Lanka, they have proper 
shit there) then just buy those insertable long lasting blades. I use

blades here costs like $2 for 10 and each single blade lasts at least 3 
months. So you just got something that lasts 2 years and 6 months (at 
least) for around 2+ whatever you got the insertable razor for, which is 
not a lot in itself, its like 7 bucks.﻿

comments.author: Zurihaha AIOC

comments.text:
Generic drugs only need to be 75% as efficacious as the original in the US. 
Furthermore, the binders, fillers, colors, and flavorings aren't always the 
same. Not important? Consider Sudafed to the generic CVS version. The name 
brand Sudafed is coated with a slick and sweet candy coating that helps to 
swallow them. The generic is bitter, and has a tendency to stick. My 
girlfriend has a hard time taking pills, and thus the namebrand is far 
easier for her to take.

Also, bottled water can be spring water, compared to tap or reverse osmosis 
water. What's the difference? Reverse osmosis lacks the salts and minerals 
that spring water has, giving it, in my opinion, a bland and terrible 
taste. Tap water isn't bad, but still doesn't have the mineral content of 
spring water. I like well water a lot too, considering the well isn't taken 
from an area high in sulfur. In fact, I like wells and springs high in 
iron. Personal preference.﻿

comments.author: Kristen225

comments.text:
In regards to the premium petrol, or 91 octane fuel: If your car needs it, 
USE it. Some engines are designed to have higher compression, in which 
regular fuel does not do as well.

I've used both regular and premium. Sure, while premium is more expensive 
at the pump, I've noticed that my engine will "waste" regular fuel- I found 
myself at the pump more often using regular than premium. If you drive a 
Japanese vehicle, chances are you should be using premium.﻿
